The foundations of quantum theory have been the subject of intense debate for the past century. The most prominent reconstruction programs have been those of von Neumann, Mackey, Piron, and Abramsky and Coecke. In this paper, we provide a purely categorical approach to the foundations of quantum theory. The axioms are purely categorical and do not presuppose any analytical structure. This approach is more general than the reconstruction programs and is applicable to any category of states.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic obligate parasites that cause diseases in both invertebrates and vertebrates. The evolutionary origin of the myxozoan body plan, which is characterized by a distinctive structure, the polar capsule, is unknown. Here, we report the first comparative analysis of the transcriptome and genome of two distantly related myxozoans and a less reduced cnidarian parasite. Our results show that myxozoans are a sister group to the less reduced cnidarian parasite, and that the extreme reduction in genome size and gene content is a defining feature of the myxozoan lineage. These results provide insight into the origin of the myxozoan body plan and the evolution of parasitic lifestyles. (Show more)

The world’s population is expected to reach 10 billion by 2050, and the global food supply will need to increase by 60% to feed this larger population. Earlier studies suggest that crop yields will decline as the optimum growing temperature is exceeded, and that the variability of yields will increase. Here, we quantify the magnitude of these effects for maize production and climate variability in the major maize-producing and -exporting countries. We find that the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year increases from 0% to 86% under 4 °C of global warming. These results highlight the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance. They also underscore the importance of international grain trade and the vulnerability of the world’s poor to food price spikes. Our results are especially relevant in the context of the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic.

We find that many small businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Moreover, many small businesses are financially fragile, with only a few weeks of cash on hand. Finally, many small businesses expect the crisis to last for many months. These findings have important implications for policymakers seeking to support small businesses during the crisis.

The accumulation of plastic debris in the ocean has become a major environmental concern. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unclear. We show that the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This discrepancy is explained by the selective removal of small plastic fragments by the ocean interior. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean. This study is a major step forward in the understanding of the global distribution of plastic debris in the ocean. It will be a key reference for future studies.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. Several studies point to α-syn oligomerization and aggregation as a mediator of neurotoxicity in synucleinopathies including MSA. Here we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. This effect is associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn and with neuroprotective effects. These results suggest that VX-765 is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This study opens the way to the development of a clinical trial in MSA patients. This would be the first clinical trial in a synucleinopathy. The results of this trial would be of great interest to the synucleinopathy community.

The hemoglobin (Hb) system is essential for the survival of all vertebrates. The Hb system is also a target for therapeutic intervention in a variety of diseases. The Hb system is regulated by a complex network of transcription factors and miRNAs. Here we investigated the role of the insulin-like growth factor 2 mRNA-binding protein 1 (IGF2BP1) in the regulation of Hb expression. We show that IGF2BP1 is expressed in the erythroid lineage and that its expression is developmentally regulated. We also show that IGF2BP1 can mediate the loss of HbA in favor of HbF. These results suggest that IGF2BP1 may be a target for therapeutic intervention in hemoglobinopathies. This study also provides a potential mechanism for chronoregulation of Hb expression in humans. Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure. The most common treatment for hypertension is the use of drugs that block the voltage-gated L-type Ca2+ channel (Cav1.2). However, these drugs are associated with a higher risk of heart failure. Here, we show that these drugs activate the Ca2+ sensor STIM1, which in turn activates the plasma membrane ORAI channels. Our findings suggest that the use of these drugs should be limited to patients with mild hypertension.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We used >25 years of bird surveys to test whether the NWFP had the intended effect on biodiversity. We found that the policy had a strong influence on forest composition, but the effects on bird populations were more complex. The NWFP halted clearcutting on federal land, but this has so far been insufficient to reverse declines in older-forest–associated bird populations. We conclude that the NWFP needs to be strengthened to ensure the conservation and development of older forests.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. This problem can be addressed by the development of new antibacterial agents to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. Computational approaches are essential tools to this end since their application enables fast and early strategical decisions in the drug development process. Here, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. The design strategy presented here is a promising approach for the rational design of new antibiotics. The compounds designed by us are available for licensing. Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. Popular network architectures often add additional operations and connections to the standard architecture to enable training deeper networks. To achieve accurate results in practice, a large number of trainable parameters are often required. Here, we introduce a network architecture based on using dilated convolutions to capture features at different image scales and densely connecting all feature maps with each other. The resulting architecture is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters and consists of a single set of operations, making it easier to implement, train, and apply in practice, and automatically adapts to different problems. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. Our results suggest that the proposed network architecture is a promising approach for solving many image-processing problems. The code is available at https://github.com/yifanwang123/dilated-cnn.git.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. The role of CTLA-4 in the regulation of immune responses is well established, but the specific contribution of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmune diseases is still unclear. Here, we show that the deletion of CTLA-4 in adult mice leads to a variety of autoimmune diseases, which are not fatal. However, congenital deficiency is not lethal. This indicates that the role of CTLA-4 in the regulation of immune responses is not only limited to the regulation of T cell responses.

The order Coleoptera (beetles) is arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding (herbivory) on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics. (Show more)

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. Population size was manipulated such that participants could learn from the paper planes constructed by one, two, or four models from the prior generation. These social-learning conditions were compared with an asocial individual-learning condition in which individual participants made repeated attempts at constructing a paper plane, without having access to any planes produced by other participants. Larger populations generated greater variation in plane performance and gave participants access to better-adapted planes, but this did not enhance CCE. In fact, there was an inverse relationship between population size and CCE: plane flight distance did not improve over the experimental generations in the 2-Model and 4-Model conditions, but did improve over generations in the 1-Model social-learning condition. The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is separated from the outer core by a brittle boundary. The inner core is thought to have formed by crystallization of molten iron. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still controversial. We demonstrate that the bcc phase of iron is more stable than the hcp phase under inner core conditions. Thus, the bcc phase is likely to be the first phase to nucleate, instead of the hcp phase. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. Our results provide a new perspective on the formation of the inner core. (Show more)

The use of marijuana has increased dramatically in the United States, and the number of states that have legalized it has grown. The legal availability of marijuana has led to a need to understand its effects on the brain. Here, we show that the brain’s reactivity to methylphenidate (a drug that elevates extracellular dopamine [DA]) is reduced in people who use marijuana. This reduced reactivity may contribute to the negative emotionality and addictive behaviors of marijuana abusers.

The human brain is the most powerful computer ever built. How does it work? A major avenue of investigation is to study how its design is reflected in its computation. Here, we show that the most powerful language models in the world also predict the vast majority of the neural activity in the human brain when both are activated by language. This suggests that the brain’s language machinery is fundamentally a predictive computation. We also find that the predictive power of these models is correlated with their accuracy on a challenging language task. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the language comprehension mechanisms in the human brain. They also suggest that the brain may be able to use these models to help us understand language and may even be using them right now.

Deep learning (DL) has been a revolutionary success in many scientific computing problems. However, it is not clear whether the success of DL is due to its ability to approximate any function, or whether it is due to its instability. We show that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable neural networks (NNs), but there does not exist any algorithm that can train such a NN. This is a fundamental result that will help us understand the limits of deep learning.

This argument is based on a classic psychological experiment published 45 years ago. We discuss the flaws of this experiment and show that it is not surprising that people fail to understand it. We also discuss the implications of this study for the study of human behavior.

The dynamics of entanglement in isolated quantum systems is a fundamental question of quantum information theory and statistical mechanics. It is also of great interest for condensed-matter physics, where it is a key ingredient in the understanding of the thermodynamics of isolated systems. The entanglement dynamics is usually studied by means of numerical simulations, which are computationally demanding and can be performed only for a limited number of systems. Here, we develop a method that allows for a complete analytical description of the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain, which is a solvable model in condensed-matter physics. Our work provides a powerful tool for the study of the entanglement dynamics in a wide class of quantum many-body systems.

The COVID-19 pandemic has claimed the lives of more than 5.5 million people worldwide. The only available vaccines are based on inactivated virus, which is associated with severe adverse effects. To overcome this limitation, we developed a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine. The vaccine is temperature sensitive in vitro, but robustly grows at the permissive temperature. In hamsters, the vaccine is more than 90% protective against lethal challenge with the wild-type virus. The vaccine is also highly effective in a mouse model of infection. This, coupled with its large-scale manufacturing potential, supports its potential use in mass vaccination programs. The vaccine is a promising candidate for the global fight against COVID-19. The Second Pandemic of plague, which occurred between the 14th and 19th centuries, led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of plague during this period is unknown, but it is thought to have been spread by rats. Here, we present a mathematical model of plague transmission by a human ectoparasite vector. We show that this model fits mortality curves from nine outbreaks in Europe better than models for rodent transmission. Our results support that human ectoparasites were primary vectors for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death (1346–1353), ultimately challenging the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats. This work also provides a framework for future studies of the role of human ectoparasites in the spread of plague.

The evolution of brain size has been a central topic in the study of animal cognition. However, the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is more complex than just the evolution of brain size. This study shows that the evolution of brain information-processing capacity is better understood by using the number of neurons rather than brain size. The mitochondrial molecular chaperone TRAP1 is a promising target for cancer therapy. However, the utility of current TRAP1 inhibitors as probes of TRAP1 function is questionable because they cannot distinguish between TRAP1 and HSP90, the target of many currently available TRAP1 inhibitors. We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. This work provides a mechanistic explanation for the antitumor activity of TRAP1 inhibitors and suggests that TRAP1 may be a promising target for cancer therapy

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a key regulator of the actin cytoskeleton. It is involved in a variety of processes, including cell migration, cell division, and cell differentiation. However, the mechanism by which ADF regulates actin dynamics is not well understood. Here, we show that ADF can induce a mechanical torque on actin filaments, which enhances severing. This mechanism is important for ADF to efficiently sever highly connected filament networks, such as those found in cell-cell adhesions. Our results provide a mechanism for how ADF can regulate the mechanical properties of the actin cytoskeleton. Our findings are relevant to a variety of processes, including cell migration, cell division, and cell differentiation. Our results also have implications for understanding the role of ADF in human diseases. Fructose, a common sweetener, is often used in combination with glucose in soft drinks and other foods. The present study shows that fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation in response to food cues and greater hunger and desire for food. These findings suggest that fructose may be a weaker suppressor of appetite than glucose. The results also suggest that the effects of fructose on brain and behavior may be mediated, at least in part, by the hormone insulin. These findings have implications for understanding the effects of sugar-sweetened beverages on health and for developing strategies to reduce consumption of these beverages. Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across Madagascar, from the north to the south, from the east to the west. We found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The recent demographic history of Madagascar is also reflected in the genomic diversity, with a strong influence of geography on the genetic structure of the population. The results suggest that Madagascar was settled by multiple waves of people, with a strong influence of geography on the settlement of the island. This is important to understand the history of Madagascar and the Indian Ocean. (Show more)

We show that people’s emotions can be influenced by the emotions of others, even when they are not interacting with those others. This is a form of emotional contagion, and it is well established in laboratory experiments. However, the results of previous experiments are controversial, and some have suggested that it is not possible to observe emotional contagion in the real world. Our results show that it is possible to observe emotional contagion in the real world, and that it is not necessary for people to interact with others in person for emotions to be transferred. This work also suggests that people’s positive emotions are positively influenced by the positive emotions of others, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. These results have implications for our understanding of the spread of emotions in society.

The vast majority of RNA in the cell is not protein-coding, and noncoding RNAs can have important roles in cell function. One of the most common modifications of noncoding RNAs is the pseudouridine (Ψ) modification, which is present in the coding regions of mRNAs. We show that the presence of Ψ in mRNA can alter translation. We find that the presence of Ψ can promote the low-level synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence in the reconstituted translation system as well as human cells, and increases the rate of near-cognate Val-tRNAVal reacting on a ΨUU codon. The vast majority of Ψ moieties in mRNAs are found in coding regions, and our study suggests that one consequence of the ribosome encountering Ψ can be to modestly alter both translation speed and mRNA decoding. These findings have implications for the function of noncoding RNAs and the regulation of protein synthesis. (Show more)

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we investigate the wider implications of this feeling with a sample of 7,304 men and women aged 50 and older. We show that independently of age, sex, educational attainment, and socioeconomic status, higher worthwhile ratings are associated with stronger personal relationships, broader social engagement, less loneliness, greater prosperity, better mental and physical health, less chronic pain, less disability, more favorable biomarker profiles, healthier lifestyles, and less time spent alone or watching television. Longitudinally over a 4-y period, worthwhile ratings predict positive changes in social, economic, health, and behavioral outcomes independently of baseline levels. The feeling that life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages. This study has implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

The evolution of body size in mammals is a central topic in evolutionary biology. The aquatic mammals are a particularly interesting group to study this topic because of the unique challenges they face in the water. We use a combination of comparative phylogenetic analysis and the fossil record to show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These three independent body size increases and a shared aquatic optimum size are consistent with control by differences in the scaling of energetic intake and cost functions with body size between the terrestrial and aquatic realms. The aquatic medium confines aquatic mammals to larger body sizes. This study provides a quantitative test of the energetic constraints of the aquatic medium. (Show more)

The common cold is the most common viral infection worldwide, and rhinovirus is the main cause of the common cold. The temperature dependence of rhinovirus replication has been attributed to a reduced antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. Here, we show that mouse airway cells infected with mouse-adapted rhinovirus exhibit a striking enrichment in expression of antiviral defense response genes at 37 °C relative to 33 °C. This temperature-dependent induction of antiviral defense response is dependent on the MAVS protein, a key signaling adaptor of the RIG-I–like receptors (RLRs). Stimulation of mouse airway cells with the synthetic RLR ligand poly I:C leads to greater induction of type I IFN at 37 °C relative to 33 °C. Genetic deficiency of MAVS or the type I IFN receptor in infected airway cells permits higher levels of viral replication, particularly at 37 °C, and partially rescues the temperature-dependent growth phenotype. These findings demonstrate that in mouse airway cells, rhinovirus replicates preferentially at nasal cavity temperature due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. Bacteria use a variety of mechanisms to sense their environment and respond appropriately. Here we show that the opportunistic pathogen Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its type IV pili to sense surfaces. This mechanism is important for the pathogen because it allows it to attach to surfaces and initiate the formation of biofilms, which are essential for its survival and pathogenicity. Our results demonstrate that type IV pili are a mechanochemical sensor that regulates the activity of the Chp chemosensory system, which in turn regulates the expression of virulence factors and biofilm formation. These findings have important implications for understanding the role of type IV pili in bacterial motility and virulence. They also suggest that type IV pili may be a general mechanism used by bacteria to sense their environment. This is an important area of research that will continue to be of interest to the scientific community.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the last decades, and the use of insecticides in particular has been associated with a decline in aquatic biodiversity. However, the extent of the problem is still poorly understood. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global occurrence of pesticides in surface waters. Our results show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. We also show that the use of pesticides in agriculture is not only a problem in the countries with the most stringent environmental regulations. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a more comprehensive understanding of the ecology of emerging viruses. In this study, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer. Our findings suggest that deer may be a reservoir for SARS-CoV-2, and that the virus has the potential to circulate in this species. Our results also highlight the need for a more comprehensive “One Health” approach to study the ecology and evolution of emerging viruses. This study has important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic. (Show more)

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, people, and climate change. This paper examines the causes of the proliferation of large dams in the developing world, the problems they cause, and the solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices. We also propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) hypothesis has been the focus of much research. However, the immune system has been largely overlooked as a potential contributor to the disease. Here, we show that neurons are the primary source of inflammatory factors in the brain, and that Aβ is the primary stimulus for this response. This finding has implications for the development of new therapies, as well as the understanding of the disease process.

The earliest evidence for the economic exploitation of chickens is still unknown. The results of our faunal analysis demonstrate that the Hellenistic (fourth–second centuries B.C.E.) site of Maresha, Israel, is the earliest site known today where economic exploitation of chickens was widely practiced. We base our claim on the exceptionally high frequency of chicken bones at that site, the majority of which belong to adult individuals, and on the observed 2:1 ratio of female to male bones. These results are supported further by an extensive survey of faunal remains from 234 sites in the Southern Levant, spanning more than three millennia, which shows a sharp increase in the frequency of chicken during the Hellenistic period. We further argue that the earliest secure evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe dates to the first century B.C.E. and therefore is predated by the finds in the Southern Levant by at least a century. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later

The folding of large proteins is a major challenge in understanding the structure and function of proteins. The folding of the large two-domain maltose binding protein (MBP) was studied by a combination of methods that provide high structural resolution. The results indicate that the folding of MBP proceeds through distinct native-like intermediates in distinct pathways. These results add a large protein to the list of proteins known to fold through distinct native-like intermediates in distinct pathways. The results also suggest that the intermediates are obligatory steps on the folding pathway. The results are important for understanding the structure and function of proteins. They also provide a model for the folding of other large proteins.

The accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress has been shown to be a key mechanism for regulating gene expression in bacteria. In this study, we show that the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is known to remove the nucleoside monophosphate cap from mRNA, also removes the dinucleoside tetraphosphate cap. We demonstrate that this enzyme prefers to remove capped RNAs over their uncapped counterparts, and that it does so by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to remove the cap from mRNA. The unique manner in which capped substrates of this kind bind to the active site of RppH positions the δ-phosphate, rather than the β-phosphate, for hydrolytic attack, generating triphosphorylated RNA as the primary product of decapping. This study reveals a previously unknown role for RppH in regulating gene expression. (Show more)

Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality and poor clinical outcomes. The mechanisms involved in the development of immunosuppression during sepsis are not fully understood. Here, we show that arginine, a key amino acid, is essential for the maintenance of T cell function and proliferation during sepsis. We also show that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, is more efficient than arginine in restoring T cell function and proliferation. These results suggest that citrulline could be a promising therapeutic strategy to improve the clinical outcome of sepsis patients. This study provides evidence for developing clinical studies with citrulline in sepsis. (Show more)

The biomass of all living organisms is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the biosphere. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We find that the kingdoms of life concentrate at different locations on the planet; plants (≈450 Gt C, the dominant kingdom) are primarily terrestrial, whereas animals (≈2 Gt C) are mainly marine, and bacteria (≈70 Gt C) and archaea (≈7 Gt C) are predominantly located in deep subsurface environments. We show that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers, thus increasing the scope of previous observations on inverse food pyramids. Finally, we highlight that the mass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined and report the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature and in physics, where systems can self-regulate their activity level. The most famous example is the sandpile model, where the activity level of the system is the number of grains of sand on the system. In this paper, we study the sandpile model in the continuum limit, where the activity level is a continuous variable. We show that the model exhibits a phase transition between a critical state and a noncritical state. We also show that the model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena. Our aim is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction between the sexes. In this study, we use proteomics to characterize the life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and determine the extent of molecular continuity between males and females. We show that the male–female interface is dynamic, with multiple proteins initially associating with sperm and then being removed from the sperm proteome after mating. In contrast, female-derived proteins begin to associate with sperm immediately after mating and comprise nearly 20% of the postmating sperm proteome. These findings provide a comprehensive characterization of the life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome and expand our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. The A1 domain in VWF binds to glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) on platelets, in a reaction triggered, in part, by alterations in flow during bleeding. The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the human virome, the set of viruses that interact with humans, has been difficult to study because of the small number of viruses compared with bacteria. We have developed a method to study the human virome that is able to study the virome in large numbers of samples. We have used this method to study the human virome in a large number of samples, and we have found that the human virome is much larger than previously thought. We have also found that the human virome is associated with many diseases. This study will help to advance our understanding of the human microbiome and human disease.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system. However, the ACI is complex and difficult to be well represented in current climate models. Progress on understanding ACI processes is hampered by inadequate observational capability. High-resolution and simultaneous observations of diurnal aerosol loading and cloud microphysical properties are challenging for current remote-sensing techniques. To overcome this conundrum, we introduce the dual-field-of-view (FOV) high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) for simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties, especially water cloud microphysical properties. Continuous observations of aerosols and clouds using this instrument, verified by the Monte Carlo simulation and coincident observations of other techniques, were conducted to investigate the interactions between aerosol loading and water cloud microphysical properties. A case study over Beijing highlights the scientific potential of dual-FOV HSRL to become a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. The observed water cloud profiles identify that due to air entrainment its vertical structure is not perfectly adiabatic, as assumed by many current retrieval methods. These observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a topic of interest for many years. The temperature of the surface of the Earth today is known to be strongly correlated with the amount of light available to organisms. This correlation has been demonstrated in the fossil record, and it is this correlation that has been used to infer the temperature of the surface of the Earth in the past. Here, we demonstrate that the temperature of the surface of the Earth in the past was also strongly correlated with the amount of light available to organisms. This finding has implications for the evolution of life on Earth.

Ion channels regulate ion flow by opening and closing their pore gates. K+ channels commonly possess two pore gates, one at the intracellular end for fast channel activation/deactivation and the other at the selectivity filter for slow C-type inactivation/recovery. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel lacks a classic intracellular bundle-crossing activation gate and normally show no C-type inactivation. We hypothesized that the BK channel’s activation gate may spatially overlap or coexist with the C-type inactivation gate at or near the selectivity filter. We induced C-type inactivation in BK channels and studied the relationship between activation/deactivation and C-type inactivation/recovery. We observed prominent slow C-type inactivation/recovery in BK channels by an extreme low concentration of extracellular K+ together with a Y294E/K/Q/S or Y279F mutation whose equivalent in Shaker channels (T449E/K/D/Q/S or W434F) caused a greatly accelerated rate of C-inactivation or constitutive C-inactivation. The malaria parasite must overcome a number of physical barriers to successfully invade the red blood cell (RBC) and initiate infection. The red cell is a highly deformable cell, and the parasite must be able to squeeze through the narrowest of gaps to reach the interior of the cell. Here, we show that the malaria parasite binds to the surface of the RBC and alters the physical properties of the cell membrane. We show that this change in the physical properties of the cell membrane is critical for the parasite to successfully invade the RBC. This work represents a major change in our understanding of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting it is, in fact, a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. This work has important implications for the development of antimalarial drugs that target the parasite’s ability to alter the physical properties of the host cell. (Show more)

Diamond is a promising material for many applications, but its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to strain. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under strain, and that its bandgap can be tuned continuously from indirect to direct. These findings open up opportunities for tailoring the properties of diamond for applications in electronics, photonics, and quantum technologies.

Influenza virus infection is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks of influenza virus correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. The impact of humidity on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low humidity makes them more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. Single-cell RNA sequencing revealed that induction of IFN-stimulated genes in response to viral infection was diminished in multiple cell types in the lung of mice housed in low humidity condition. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide mechanistic insights into the impact of ambient humidity on influenza virus infection and disease outcome. They also suggest that low humidity may be a modifiable risk factor for influenza virus infection. Our study may also have implications for the development of influenza vaccines and antiviral therapies. (Show more)

The brain’s processing of language is often described as a tree, with words at the leaves and phrases at the branches. However, the brain’s neural activity during the construction of such structures is unknown. Here, we show that the brain’s high-gamma activity increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases when words are merged into phrases. This merge operation is consistent with a neural implementation of a bottom-up or left-corner parser of the incoming language stream. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This is the first evidence for the neural basis of sentence structure.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a key regulator of development and homeostasis. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin, Axin1 and Axin2, are differentially regulated at the transcriptional and proteostatic level. This differential regulation is important for tissue-specific regulation of the two forms of Axin. This is an important finding because it suggests that the two forms of Axin are regulated in a tissue-specific manner, which may be important for the proper functioning of the Wnt pathway.

The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain that regulates feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes animals to eat, and this effect can be blocked by lesions of the dopamine system. Here we show that this effect is mediated by a circuit that includes the ventral tegmental area (VTA) and the locus coeruleus (LC). We also show that this circuit is not involved in the regulation of hunger or satiety, suggesting that it is not involved in the regulation of normal feeding. This circuit may, however, be involved in the regulation of overeating and obesity.

Nitrogen is the most important nutrient for plant growth, and the availability of this essential element is often the limiting factor for crop production. The use of nitrogen-fixing bacteria in agriculture has been a key factor in the development of modern agriculture, but the use of these bacteria is currently limited by the need for the plants to be in close proximity to the bacteria. This work represents a key step toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled nitrogen fixation system, in which the bacteria fix N2 only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work is a significant step toward the development of a sustainable agriculture system.

We study the effects of a community-based monitoring program that facilitated transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities in the Peruvian Amazon and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management. The program’s monitors were perceived to be new authorities with influence over forest management and the monitors’ incentivized patrols were substitutes for traditional, unincentivized citizen patrols that suffer from free riding and inhibit timely community detection of and responses to deforestation. Our results suggest that the program’s monitors may have contributed to a more sustainable forest management regime.

Animals use their hearing to detect and localize acoustic signals, such as those emitted by prey or predators. The acoustic sensors of animals are constrained by the organism’s body size, and the size of the sensor is often inversely proportional to the sensor’s acoustic responsivity. Here, we show that the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius can sense acoustic signals through its web, which acts as an acoustic antenna. The spider’s web is not constrained by the organism’s body size and can be enormously enlarged to increase the spider’s acoustic responsivity. The spider also can regenerate and adjust the size of its web according to its needs. The outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function in spiders provide unique features for studying extended and regenerative sensing and designing novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation. This study also provides a unique example of outsourcing and supersizing of sensory function in animals. (Show more)

We estimate the climate and health benefits of a rapid phaseout of fossil fuel use. We find that it can avoid an excess mortality rate of 3.61 million per year from outdoor air pollution worldwide. This could be up to 5.55 million per year by additionally controlling nonfossil anthropogenic sources. Globally, fossil-fuel-related emissions account for about 65% of the excess mortality, and 70% of the climate cooling by anthropogenic aerosols. The chemical influence of air pollution on aeolian dust contributes to the aerosol cooling. Since aerosols mask the anthropogenic rise in global temperature, removing fossil-fuel-generated particles liberates 0.51 °C and all pollution particles 0.73 °C warming, reaching around 2 °C over North America and Northeast Asia. The steep temperature increase from removing aerosols can be moderated to about 0.36 °C globally by the simultaneous reduction of tropospheric ozone and methane. We conclude that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to claim lives and disrupt economies worldwide. The global distribution of COVID-19 vaccines has been uneven, with many low- and middle-income countries (LMICs) still awaiting access to vaccines. The development of a vaccine for SARS-CoV-2 that is affordable and accessible to LMICs is a global priority. Here we report the design and characterization of a SARS-CoV-2 RBD-based vaccine candidate that is well-suited for large-volume microbial production. This vaccine candidate is expected to be manufacturable at low cost, and we anticipate that it will be a valuable addition to the global COVID-19 vaccine arsenal. This work is expected to contribute to the global effort to contain the pandemic. (Show more)

The small ALKAL proteins are secreted proteins that are implicated in the development of neuroblastoma, a pediatric tumor of neural crest-derived tissues. In this study, we show that the small ALKAL proteins are ligands for human ALK and the related leukocyte tyrosine kinase (LTK). We further show that the small ALKAL proteins are involved in the development of iridophores, neural crest-derived pigment cells. Our results provide in vivo evidence of (i) activation of ALK/LTK family receptors by ALKALs and (ii) an involvement of these ligand–receptor complexes in neural crest development. Our findings have implications for the development of neuroblastoma and other neural crest-related tumors. They also suggest that small ALKAL proteins are important regulators of neural crest development. Finally, our findings suggest that small ALKAL proteins may be useful as biomarkers and therapeutic targets in neuroblastoma. This study provides a better understanding of the role of ALKALs in neural crest development and the development of neuroblastoma. It also provides a foundation for the development of small molecule inhibitors of ALKALs as therapeutic targets in neuroblastoma.

The emergence of plague as a devastating disease in human history is a well-known story, but the details of its early evolution are still largely unknown. We present 17 Yersinia pestis genomes from the Late Neolithic and Early Bronze Age period, which span a wide geographic expanse across Eurasia. Our results show that the plague lineage was nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct in the Late Neolithic, but rapidly spread across continents throughout this period. We also discover the presence of the flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, previously only identified in the Caucasus and the Volga regions, suggesting a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague. Together, these data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. (Show more)

This work examined whether the endorsement of the culturally idealized form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—accounted for unique variance in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump across seven studies (n = 2,007). Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, in the days (Studies 1 and 2) and months (Studies 3 through 6) following the 2016 American presidential election, women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. In addition, as conceptualized, HM was associated with less trust in the government (Study 3), more sexism (Study 4), more racism (Study 5), and more xenophobia (Study 6) but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The conversion of native grasslands to intensive crop production has led to massive losses of soil organic carbon (SOC) to the atmosphere. The extent to which soil health management practices can mitigate these losses remains highly uncertain. We investigated the effects of soil health management practices on SOC and microbial traits in a 29-y-old field experiment in the North Central United States. We found that soil health management practices that minimized soil disturbance, diversified crop rotations, and/or added manure or legumes to annual cropping systems increased SOC and microbial biomass, but did not increase the amount of SOC stored in the mineral fraction. These results highlight the potential of well-managed grasslands to sequester SOC and provide a climate-smart agricultural system. (Show more)

The death toll and economic loss resulting from the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) pandemic are stark reminders that we are vulnerable to zoonotic viral threats. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spillover and spread in humans. We validated the framework using data from a virus discovery project and public records of virus detections around the world. The resulting ranking of 887 wildlife viruses was validated by the known zoonotic status of 78% of the top 12. The SpillOver platform provides a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. This resource can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks.

Nectar is a reward that many plants offer to pollinators for reproduction. One of the main rewards plants offer to pollinators for visitation is nectar. Nesocodon mauritianus (Campanulaceae) produces a blood-red nectar that has been proposed to serve as a visual attractant for pollinator visitation. Here, we show that the nectar’s red color is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid termed nesocodin. We identify a series of enzymes that are necessary or sufficient for the production of this pigment. We also identify nesocodin in the red nectar of the distantly related and hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae and provide molecular evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. This work cumulatively identifies a convergently evolved trait in two vertebrate-pollinated species, suggesting that the red pigment is selectively favored and that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work also provides a new alkaloid for the study of plant–pollinator interactions. (Show more)

The genetic history of Europe during the Early Medieval period is poorly understood, as there are no population-level genome data from this time. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of 11 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, who lived mostly between 490 and 620 AD. Our data indicate that the genetic ancestry of men generally resembles that of modern northern and central Europeans, while women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity; this includes signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. In addition, we found that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These results provide insights into the genetic history of Europe during the Early Medieval period and suggest that complex demographic processes may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) currently spreads in humans and causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. First, whereas MERS-CoV prefers human DPP4 over bat DPP4 as its receptor, HKU4 shows the opposite trend. Second, in the absence of exogenous proteases, both MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes mediate pseudovirus entry into bat cells, whereas only MERS-CoV spike, but not HKU4 spike, mediates pseudovirus entry into human cells. The ability to rapidly identify the cause of undifferentiated febrile illness is critical to the early detection and control of epidemics. We used a global cloud-based metagenomic sequencing platform to investigate the pathogen landscape of undifferentiated febrile illness in a periurban population in Cambodia. We identified a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, including chikungunya virus, which presaged a national outbreak. Our findings highlight the utility of mNGS in resource-limited settings and the need for ongoing pathogen surveillance to better understand the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens. This information can be used to inform public health response and preparedness. (Show more)

The human cell relies on the lagging strand template to synthesize DNA during DNA replication. This process is performed by DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) in the presence of the PCNA sliding clamp. We have developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. We find that pol δ maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This work provides a unique view into the dynamics of the pol δ holoenzyme and its implications for DNA replication. It also provides a unique perspective into the role of the PCNA sliding clamp in DNA replication. The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in science. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of genetically encoded proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by an RNA polymerase ribozyme. In the laboratory, RNA polymerase ribozymes can now be evolved to synthesize functional RNA molecules from an RNA template, but the ability to replicate nucleic acids has been achieved only in low yield. Here, we describe a method for the complete replication of nucleic acids by RNA polymerase ribozymes. This method can be used to reconstitute the replication of genetic information in the laboratory, a step toward the reconstruction of life from RNA. The results are published in the journal Science.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also highlight the importance of the initial appearance of neighborhoods and the role of physical proximity in urban change. These results have implications for urban planning and policy, as well as for the study of urban change more broadly.

The pathogenesis of COVID-19 is complex, and the treatment is still in the stage of trial and error. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the IL-6 pathway, can reduce mortality and improve the clinical symptoms of severe and critical COVID-19 patients. Therefore, it is an effective treatment to reduce mortality.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but its excess can be toxic. The ability of fungi to regulate copper homeostasis is well established, but the existence of copper-binding natural products in fungi has not been demonstrated. Here we show that the xan biosynthetic gene cluster in Aspergillus fumigatus encodes a family of isocyanide metabolites that bind copper and impact cellular copper content. The copper-chelating properties of xan BGC isocyanide products were demonstrated in vitro and in vivo, and the ability of xanthocillin-treated Pseudomonas aeruginosa to be remediated by copper supported the copper-chelating properties of xan BGC isocyanide products. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This work provides insight into the role of fungal natural products in the regulation of metal homeostasis and the control of interactions with microbes. (Show more)

Tridymite is commonly associated with silicic volcanism, and the presence of such a mineral in a “Lake Gale” catchment environment is consistent with the geologic history of the region. The impact of late-spring frosts (LSFs) on the performance of plants and animals is well known, but the geographic distribution of LSFs and the evolutionary impact of these events on plants are poorly understood. We use a large dataset of common garden experiments to infer the leaf-out and leaf-freezing resistance strategies of woody species and to forecast forest vulnerability under the ongoing changes in LSFs. Our results show that the resistance strategies of trees are closely linked to the geographic distribution of LSFs. We find that the European and Asian temperate forests are currently experiencing increasing LSFs, and that these changes will likely affect the performance of ∼35% of the European and ∼26% of the Asian forests, but only ∼10% of the North American forests. Our findings can inform decision-making in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy. (Show more)

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, it is unclear what role these cells play in disease pathogenesis. Here we show that the development of colitis requires the transition of a subset of Th17 precursors to Th1-like cells. These cells express both Stat4 and T-bet, but not the IL-12 or IFN-γ receptors. Moreover, Th17 cells can provide “help” for the development of pathogenic Th1 cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. Understanding the mechanisms by which Th17 cells contribute to disease may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, leading to paralysis and death. The disease is heterogeneous, with different causes and different rates of progression. There is a need for disease modeling to identify disease mechanisms and develop therapeutics. We now report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like cells from living patients with ALS. This will enable high-throughput drug screening to identify compounds that can alleviate toxicity to motor neurons. This will accelerate the development of therapeutics for ALS. This method can be extended to other diseases, such as Huntington’s disease, to enable rapid disease modeling and drug screening. The gut microbiota of Ixodes scapularis ticks plays a critical role in the transmission of the emerging pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum, the cause of human granulocytic anaplasmosis. We now show that A. phagocytophilum induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), which alters the gut microbiota and enhances the transmission of A. phagocytophilum. IAFGP binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the peptidoglycan cell wall of bacteria, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These data elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an antibacterial protein from an arthropod to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of the gut microbiota in the transmission of Anaplasma phagocytophilum and other pathogens. It also provides a model for the use of arthropod antibacterial proteins as a target for the development of novel antimicrobials. The evolution of the avian tail is one of the most important transitions in the history of birds. The short tail of modern birds is thought to have evolved from a long tail ending in a compound bone (pygostyle) in the group Pygostylia. The study of early members of Pygostylia is critical for understanding the origin of the modern avian bauplan. Here, we describe a new basal member of Pygostylia, Jinguofortis perplexus, and show that it represents the second earliest diverging group of the Pygostylia. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding mosaic evolution in early birds. We show that stratospheric water vapor variations play an important role in the evolution of our climate. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause. Vertebrates have a variety of colors, ranging from red to blue. The color of an animal is determined by the absorption spectrum of its pigments. In some species, the absorption spectrum is modified by the presence of proteins that bind the pigments. These proteins are called color-modifying proteins. In this study, we describe a new class of color-modifying proteins in vertebrates. These proteins bind biliverdin, the pigment that is the main component of the green pigment, chlorophyll. We show that these proteins are most similar to human alpha-1-antitrypsin, but with a remarkable functional diversification. Our results present molecular and functional evidence of recurrent evolution of chlorosis, describe a biliverdin-binding protein in vertebrates, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. This study provides a unique example of the functional diversification of a serpin. (Show more)

The ability of cancer cells to maintain their stemness properties is critical for their ability to metastasize and survive in the tumor microenvironment. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces expression of the m6A demethylase AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which in turn increases the expression of pluripotency factor NANOG and the stemness phenotype of breast cancer cells. These findings suggest that ALKBH5 may be a therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer. This study also provides a mechanism for the role of m6A in the regulation of breast cancer stem cells. Thus, ALKBH5 may be a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer. The earliest pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century. The source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. The Latin term abortivum in many sources has led some scholars to suggest that fetal calves or sheep skins were used. Others have argued that it would not be possible to sustain herds if so many pocket Bibles were made from fetal skins, arguing instead for unexpected alternatives, such as rabbit. Here, we report a simple and objective method using standard conservation treatments to identify the animal origin of parchment. The noninvasive method is a variant on zooarchaeology by mass spectrometry (ZooMS) peptide mass fingerprinting but extracts protein from the parchment surface by using an electrostatic charge generated by gentle rubbing of a PVC eraser on the membrane surface. Using this method, we analyzed 72 pocket Bibles originating in France, England, and Italy and 293 additional parchment samples that bracket this period. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe extinction event in the last 542 My. The age model for the extinction is critical to understanding its cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics. We present a new age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dating of volcanic ash beds. The age model is based on five ash beds, each of which is interpreted as a major extinction event. The extinction occurred between 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. Onset of a major reorganization of the carbon cycle immediately precedes the initiation of extinction and is punctuated by a sharp (3‰), short-lived negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. The carbon cycle volatility persists for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. (Show more)

Retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is a member of the nuclear receptor superfamily and plays important roles in various biological processes, such as metabolism, cancer, and circadian rhythm. However, the role of RORα in the intestinal epithelium is still unclear. Here, we generate intestinal epithelial cell (IEC)-specific RORα-deficient (RORαΔIEC) mice and find that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORαΔIEC mice exhibit excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Transcriptome analysis reveals that deletion of RORα leads to up-regulation of NF-κB target genes in IECs. Chromatin immunoprecipitation analysis reveals corecruitment of RORα and histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3) on NF-κB target promoters and subsequent dismissal of CREB binding protein (CBP) and bromodomain-containing protein 4 (BRD4) for transcriptional repression. The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the development of vaccines and therapeutics. The D614G mutation in the spike protein is the most common mutation in the virus currently circulating in the United States. We use cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the spike protein with and without this mutation. We find that the D614G mutation leads to a more open conformation of the spike protein that may facilitate binding to the receptor and subsequent structural rearrangements required for membrane fusion. This work provides a structural basis for the increased infectivity of the D614G mutant virus. (Show more)

We study the problem of finding a Nash equilibrium in a repeated game with Borel-measurable payoffs. We show that, under mild assumptions, the set of Nash equilibria is a Borel set. This result is of independent interest, and it is also a key step in the proof of our main theorem, which shows that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States, with Black and Latino Americans experiencing a disproportionate burden of morbidity and mortality. We estimate life expectancy at birth and at age 65 y for 2020, for the total US population and by race and ethnicity, using four scenarios of deaths—one in which the COVID-19 pandemic had not occurred and three including COVID-19 mortality projections produced by the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation. Our medium estimate indicates a reduction in US life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y to 77.48 y, lower than any year since 2003. We also project a 0.87-y reduction in life expectancy at age 65 y. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. The chemical properties of atoms are essential to the understanding of the chemical behavior of compounds. The chemical hardness and electronegativity are two central properties of atoms that can be seen as the first- and second-order chemical potentials. Here, we calculate, as a function of pressure, two central chemical properties of atoms, electronegativity and chemical hardness, which can be seen as the first- and second-order chemical potentials. We find that for most elements, chemical hardness and electronegativity decrease with pressure, consistent with pressure-induced metallization. Furthermore, we discover that pressure-induced s-d orbital transfer makes Ni, Pd, and Pt “pseudo–noble-gas” atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements preceding them (Fe and, especially, Co, Rh, and Ir) electron acceptors, while the elements right after them (Cu, Ag, Zn, and Cd) become highly electropositive. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales. This work is a step toward the understanding of the chemical behavior of matter under pressure.
