Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and severity of wildfires, which can alter the carbon cycle. However, the magnitude of this effect is uncertain because of the complexity of the interactions between fire, climate, and the carbon cycle. We show that changes in human demography can reduce the frequency of wildfires, which can reduce warming. This effect is most effective under lower emissions scenarios, suggesting that fire management and climate policy are complementary in reducing global warming. Our results highlight the importance of fire in the carbon cycle and the need to understand the feedbacks between climate, fire, and the carbon cycle.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their tissues. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are not well understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the provision of a single glycan to its symbiotic luminescent bacteria, Vibrio fischeri, at a specific time of day. This glycan is catabolized by the bacteria, which is required for their maintenance and for the periodic acidification of the crypts, which enhances their ability to produce light at night. This glycan-mediated regulation of the symbionts’ habitat may be a general mechanism used by animals to control the activities of their associated microbes. (Show more)

We present a method to identify latent patterns in text data. We use a generative model to identify a set of topics that best explain the data. We then represent documents as topic sequences. This method is particularly useful for text data that is too large to be read in its entirety. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System (NVDRS). The NVDRS summarizes violent death incidents with structured variables and unstructured narratives. We identify 225 latent topics in the narratives (e.g., preparation for death and physical aggression); many of these topics are not captured by existing structured variables. We then compare the gender bias of topics to their prevalence in narratives of female versus male victims. Results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. It can be applied to any domain, and to any text data that is too large to be read in its entirety. It can also be extended to other types of data, such as images. Our method is a step toward a more data-driven understanding of the world.

The second plague pandemic, which started with the arrival of the Black Death in Europe in 1347 CE, lasted for four centuries. This event is generally understood as the consequence of a single introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. To locate these putative plague reservoirs, we studied the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics, based on a dataset of 7,711 georeferenced historical plague outbreaks and 15 annually resolved tree-ring records from Europe and Asia. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. This study provides a new perspective on the history of the Black Death and the role of climate in its spread. (Show more)

The sea star wasting disease (SSWD) is a devastating disease affecting populations of at least 20 species of asteroids on the Pacific Coast of North America. The disease is characterized by rapid degradation of the animal. We show that a densovirus is the most likely cause of the disease. We also show that the virus is present in the environment and in other echinoderms, suggesting that the virus is spread by the movement of infected animals. This is the first report of a densovirus causing mass mortality in sea stars.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia and is associated with a poor survival rate. There is an urgent need for novel and more efficient therapies, ideally targeting AML stem cells that are essential for maintaining the disease. We show here that monoclonal antibodies targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We demonstrate that effector-cell–mediated killing is essential for the observed therapeutic effects and that natural killer cells constitute a critical human effector cell type. Because IL-1 signaling is important for the growth of AML cells, we generated an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling and show that this antibody suppresses the proliferation of primary human AML cells. Hence, IL1RAP can be efficiently targeted with an anti-IL1RAP antibody capable of both achieving antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity and blocking of IL-1 signaling as modes of action. Collectively, these results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This study provides a proof-of-concept for the use of antibodies targeting IL1RAP as a treatment for AML. This

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample at high resolution the genomic diversity (including maternal lineages, paternal lineages, and genome-wide data) across 257 villages and 2,704 Malagasy individuals. We find a common Bantu and Austronesian descent for all Malagasy individuals with a limited paternal contribution from Europe and the Middle East. Admixture and demographic growth happened recently, suggesting a rapid settlement of Madagascar during the last millennium. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, there are geographic influences on the present genomic diversity, independent of the admixture, showing that a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. Our results provide a new perspective on the history of Madagascar. They also highlight the importance of considering the spatial resolution of the sampling when studying the history of human populations. Bacteria have evolved small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA. Consistent with this observation, we found that cadA and galE are repressed by base pairing with the RNA (denoted AzuR). The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our approach can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of next-generation vaccines and therapeutics. (Show more)

Agricultural production is a key driver of the global economy, and the ability to monitor crop status in a timely and accurate manner is critical to ensure food security. However, the vast majority of agricultural production is still conducted by smallholder farmers, who are often unaware of the latest technologies and are difficult to reach. This paper demonstrates that the use of crop expert surveys can overcome these challenges and provide a cost-effective and scalable solution to monitor crop status. We show that the US Department of Agriculture’s Crop Progress and Condition survey, despite its subjective nature, can be transformed into a continuous and probabilistic variable that can be used to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. This work has important implications for the agricultural sector, as well as for the development of new technologies that rely on the use of large-scale, continuous crop monitoring systems.

Language is a complex system that involves the integration of information over time. The neural basis of this integration is not well understood. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is sensitive to the duration of memory. This mechanism is not reliant on the maintenance of high firing rates, and it is not limited to the maintenance of a single piece of information. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The soil is a major carbon reservoir, and its respiration is a major flux in the global carbon cycle. Despite considerable scientific attention in recent decades, the overall response of soil respiration to anticipated climatic warming remains unclear. We synthesize the largest global dataset to date of soil respiration, moisture, and temperature measurements, totaling >3,800 observations representing 27 temperature manipulation studies, spanning nine biomes and over 2 decades of warming. Our analysis reveals no significant differences in the temperature sensitivity of soil respiration between control and warmed plots in all biomes, with the exception of deserts and boreal forests. Thus, our data provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, contrary to the results from multiple single-site studies. Our analysis adds a unique cross-biome perspective on the temperature response of soil respiration, information critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming. The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is one of the most important evolutionary events in the history of life. It is also one of the most challenging to model, as it involves the loss of a major function of the cell, photosynthesis. Here, we show that the transition to a parasitic lifestyle, characterized by the parasite’s dependence on a host to fulfill its life cycle, rather than the loss of photosynthesis, is linked to the relaxation of functional constraints on the plastid genome. Our findings suggest that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. During the functional reduction process, the elevation of evolutionary rates reaches several new rate equilibria, possibly relating to the modified protein turnover rates in heterotrophic plastids. This study provides a new perspective on the molecular evolution of the plastid genome and its role in the origin and evolution of life. (Show more)

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought was a stark reminder of the vulnerability of South Africa and other water-scarce regions to climate extremes. We use a high-resolution large ensemble to estimate the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5 [SSP2-4.5]) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. (Show more)

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has been a major advance in the study of materials. The first known example of a naturally occurring quasicrystal was found in the Khatyrka meteorite, which fell in the Russian Arctic in 1920. The discovery of the trinitite quasicrystal in the Trinity test of 1945, the first nuclear explosion, is of similar historical significance. The trinitite quasicrystal is the oldest known anthropogenic (made by humans) quasicrystal, and its discovery provides a link between the discovery of the first naturally occurring quasicrystal and the first nuclear explosion. Photosynthesis relies on these modified tetrapyrroles for the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring, the key reaction in the biosynthesis of (bacterio)chlorophyll, has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated cyclase enzymes using different chemistries. The majority of anoxygenic phototrophic bacteria use BchE, an O2-sensitive [4Fe-4S] cluster protein, whereas plants, cyanobacteria, and some phototrophic bacteria possess an O2-dependent enzyme, the major catalytic component of which is a diiron protein, AcsF. Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in multiple sclerosis (MS) and other neurodegenerative diseases. Neuroactive protein kinase ASK1 has been implicated in neuroinflammation, but its precise cellular and molecular mechanisms remain unknown. In this study, we generated conditional knockout (CKO) mice that lack ASK1 in T cells, dendritic cells, microglia/macrophages, microglia, or astrocytes, to assess the roles of ASK1 during experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE). We found that neuroinflammation was reduced in both the early and later stages of EAE in microglia/macrophage-specific ASK1 knockout mice, whereas only the later-stage neuroinflammation was ameliorated in astrocyte-specific ASK1 knockout mice. ASK1 signaling in microglia played a major role in generating and maintaining disease. Activated astrocytes produce key inflammatory mediators, including CCL2, that further activated and recruited microglia/macrophages, in an astrocytic ASK1-dependent manner. The 2012–2014 California drought is the driest period in the state’s recorded history. We find that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that this increase is largely attributable to anthropogenic warming. The probability that precipitation deficits are also warm has increased, and the probability that precipitation deficits produce drought has increased. We conclude that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions like those that have created the acute human and ecosystem impacts associated with the 2012–2014 drought. The results have important implications for water resources management, ecosystem management, and wildfire risk in California and other regions of the world that are experiencing or will experience similar climate changes. The results also highlight the importance of anthropogenic climate change in understanding the recent evolution of California’s drought. Autism is a complex disorder with a multifactorial inheritance pattern. Therefore, it is difficult to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, specifically, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a unique example of a convergent mechanism across multiple autism-risk genes. This study also provides a model system for studying the molecular mechanisms of behavioral flexibility. This study will be useful for understanding the etiology of autism and for developing new treatments for autism. (Show more)

The results suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ signaling. Loss-of-function mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensing protein STIM1 result in severe immune dysfunction and myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and in the pore-forming protein of the CRAC channel that cause Stormorken syndrome, a rare disease with hematological abnormalities. Our data suggest that modulation of store-operated Ca2+ entry may be a promising therapeutic approach for patients with Stormorken syndrome. This study expands our understanding of the molecular function of the CRAC channel and suggests new therapies for patients with Stormorken syndrome and related conditions. (Show more)

The spread of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases is a key feature of the disease process and is thought to be a critical determinant of disease progression. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are poorly understood. Here we use a model of Huntington’s disease to demonstrate that protein aggregates spread through the brain in a non–cell-autonomous manner, and that this spreading is dependent on endocytosis. We also show that the release of aggregates requires active fusion of the plasma membrane. These results provide a mechanistic understanding of the spread of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

The role of bats in the emergence of zoonotic viruses is a major area of interest in the scientific community. However, the mechanisms by which bats may serve as reservoirs of viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks are not well understood. Here, we identified and characterized a protein that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. This protein, named MTX, selectively inhibits the leukotriene-A4 hydrolase function of leukotriene-A4 hydrolase to inhibit the generation of leukotriene B4, a potent lipid chemoattractant for host defense against infection. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of bats in the emergence of zoonotic viruses. (Show more)

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a key metabolic regulator. We have developed a small-molecule inhibitor of SHMT that blocks tumor growth in a mouse model of colon cancer. We have also identified a glycine import defect in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, a cancer that is notoriously resistant to treatment. These findings suggest that targeting SHMT may be a promising strategy for treating a variety of cancers. This work is a step toward the development of a new class of cancer therapeutics.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no known cause or cure. The disease is caused by the aggregation of a variety of proteins, including the well-known superoxide dismutase 1 (SOD1), the transactive response DNA binding protein 43 (TDP-43), and the fused in sarcoma (FUS) protein. Here, we show that these proteins are not merely a subset of the native interaction partners of these three proteins, which are themselves supersaturated. To explain the presence of coaggregating proteins in inclusions in the brain and spinal cord, we observe that they have an average supersaturation even greater than the average supersaturation of the native interaction partners in motor neurons, but not when scores are generated from an average of other human tissues. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This study provides a new perspective on the disease process of ALS and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

We present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold cesium (Cs) atoms. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. An optical conveyor technique is presented for continuously loading atoms into the desired trapping positions with optimal coupling to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. These 2D photonic crystal devices can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. The results are expected to be of interest to researchers in many-body physics, atom optics, and photonic crystals. The results are also expected to be of interest to researchers in the semiconductor industry, as the fabrication process is based on standard CMOS technology. The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of life. The early diversification of the flowering plants is poorly understood, and the origin of the aquatic flowering plants is even less understood. The research presented here focuses on Montsechia, a plant first recovered from the Cretaceous of the Pyrenees of Spain more than 100 y ago. The study of more than 1,000 carefully prepared specimens of Montsechia reveals that it is sister to Ceratophyllum, a plant that lives and reproduces below the surface of the water. Montsechia is the earliest known aquatic angiosperm, and its discovery raises questions about the early diversification of the flowering plants. The discovery of Montsechia also suggests that aquatic habitats may have played a major role in the diversification of some early angiosperm lineages. (Show more)

The human parvovirus B19 (B19V) is a ubiquitous pathogen that causes a number of conditions, such as fifth disease in children and arthritis and arthralgias in adults. The most recent common ancestor of all B19V has been dated to the early 1800s, and it has been suggested that genotype 1, the most common B19V genotype, only started circulating in the 1960s. Here we present 10 ancient B19V genomes (63.9–99.7% genome coverage) from dental and skeletal remains of individuals who lived in Eurasia and Greenland from ∼0.5 to ∼6.9 thousand years ago. We find that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time, and we are able to date the recombination event that formed the most common B19V genotype 2 to ∼5.0–6.8 thousand years ago. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Show more)

The rate of sea level rise is one of the most visible and well-known manifestations of climate change. In this study, we use satellite altimeter data to estimate the rate of acceleration of global mean sea level over the last 25 y. We find that the acceleration is statistically significant and is consistent with the rate predicted by climate models. The acceleration is not due to instrumental drift, and it is not explained by changes in the rate of global mass movement.

The expectation is that pain will increase with age, as the body accumulates injury, wear and tear, and disease. Consistent with that expectation, pain rises with age in other wealthy countries. However, in America today, the elderly report less pain than those in midlife. This is the mystery of American pain. We show today’s midlife Americans have had more pain throughout adulthood than did today’s elderly. Disaggregating the cross-section of ages by year of birth and completion of a bachelor’s degree, we find, for those with less education, that each successive birth cohort has a higher prevalence of pain at each age—a result not found for those with a bachelor’s degree. Thus, the gap in pain between the more and less educated has widened in each successive birth cohort. If these patterns continue, pain prevalence will continue to increase for all adults; tomorrow’s elderly will be sicker than today’s elderly, with potentially serious implications for healthcare.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. The application of NMR-assisted crystallography to the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate, a defining species for pyridoxal-5′-phosphate–dependent enzymes, provides a detailed picture of structure and reactivity. This integrated approach is able to identify the protonation states of the ionizable sites on the cofactor, substrate, and catalytic side chains as well as the location and orientation of crystallographic waters within the active site. The chemically detailed, three-dimensional structure from NMR-assisted crystallography is key to understanding why the natural substrate indole does not react, while benzimidazole is poised for, but unable to initiate, the subsequent bond formation step. This work demonstrates the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into enzyme reactions. (Show more)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no specific treatment for MERS, and the high mortality rate of the disease highlights the need for effective antiviral therapies. Remdesivir, a nucleotide analog, was shown to inhibit SARS-CoV replication in vitro and in vivo. Here, we show that prophylactic and therapeutic treatment with remdesivir in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection reduced the severity of disease and prevented the formation of lung lesions. These data support the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial for the treatment of MERS-CoV infection. It may also be considered for the treatment of other coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This is the first report of the use of remdesivir in a nonhuman primate model of MERS-CoV infection. The data presented here may also be relevant for the treatment of other viral infections caused by enveloped viruses. The use of remdesivir in the treatment of COVID-19 is discussed in the main text.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common feature of nature. However, the mechanisms by which hosts regulate the activities of their symbionts are not well understood. Here, we show that the squid Euprymna scolopes regulates the activities of its symbiotic luminescent bacteria through the strategic provision of a single glycan. This glycan is catabolized by the bacteria, which in turn modulates the conditions in which the symbionts live. This glycan-mediated regulation of symbiont activity may be a general feature of animal–microbe interactions.
This study shows that teachers’ mindsets about discipline can be changed through scalable intervention. The findings have implications for the future of American education.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can interfere with the efficiency and accuracy of DNA replication and transcription. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated how RNA polymerase II (pol II) recognizes and bypasses regioisomeric O2-, N3-, and O4-ethylthymidine (O2-, N3-, and O4-EtdT) lesions. We found that pol II stalling at O2-EtdT and N3-EtdT sites is exacerbated by TFIIS-stimulated proofreading activity. Assessment for the impact of the EtdT lesions on individual fidelity checkpoints provided further mechanistic insights, where the transcriptional lesion bypass routes for the three EtdT lesions are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. The error-free transcriptional lesion bypass route is strongly favored for the minor-groove O2-EtdT lesion. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) causes severe respiratory disease in humans. Virions must first bind to cell receptors, and then fuse with the target-cell membrane to release their genomes into the cell cytoplasm. Virions must therefore pass through the cell membrane, and must be able to resist conformational changes that occur during this passage. We found that the MERS-CoV S glycoproteins must be cleaved sequentially, first during their secretion through the exocytic organelles of virus-producing cells, and second after virus binding to target-cell receptors. We also found that the first cleavages are required for virions to resist conformational changes that occur during passage through the cell membrane, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. These findings have implications for the design of vaccines and antiviral therapies. (Show more)

The food system is responsible for a large proportion of greenhouse gas emissions and land use change. The food choices of the global population have the potential to make a significant contribution to reducing these emissions. However, the food system is also responsible for a large proportion of obesity and diet-related disease. This study demonstrates that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in a catering setting can have a large impact on sales. This suggests that increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in the food system as a whole could have a large impact on greenhouse gas emissions and obesity. This is a simple and low-cost intervention that could be implemented in a wide range of settings. The results of this study have important implications for the food system as a whole.

The cell surface proteome is the interface for the cell to interact with the extracellular space. Here we apply quantitative proteomics of N-linked glycoproteins to reveal how a collection of some 700 surface proteins is dramatically remodeled in a collection of isogenic breast epithelial cell lines stably expressing any of six of the most prominent proliferative oncogenes, including the receptor tyrosine kinases, EGFR and HER2, and downstream signaling partners such as KRAS, BRAF, MEK, and AKT. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a step toward understanding the role of the cell surface proteome in cancer and other diseases. The 2020 presidential election is expected to be the most important election in the United States in a generation. In response, many scholars and policy makers are urging the United States to expand voting-by-mail programs to safeguard the electoral process. What are the effects of vote-by-mail? In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effect of universal vote-by-mail—a policy under which every voter is mailed a ballot in advance of the election—on electoral outcomes. We find that universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our results suggest that vote-by-mail is a safe and effective way to conduct elections during the COVID-19 pandemic.

The SARS-CoV-2 virus has caused a global pandemic, with the development of vaccines and therapeutics being the primary focus for the global scientific community. However, the molecular basis for the severity and rapid spread of the disease is largely unknown. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein that has been proposed to interfere with immune responses. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2, which may be important for immune evasion. These results provide a molecular understanding of the unique immune evasion and evasion of the host innate immune response activities of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8. This knowledge will be critical for the development of future therapeutics. (Show more)

Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema. However, the underlying mechanisms are not well understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia triggers cerebral edema in rats and that this is mediated by the release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus. CRF acts on the cerebral cortex via its receptor CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in cortical astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. This study provides a better understanding of the mechanisms of cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapies. (Show more)

The problem of selective inference is of great importance in the era of big data. The challenge is to assess the strength of associations in the face of the fact that we have “cherry picked” the data. This paper describes some recent developments in selective inference and their application to forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis. The goal is to provide a framework for understanding the strengths and limitations of these methods.

The development of endothelial cells (ECs) is a complex process that requires the coordinated expression of multiple transcription factors. In this study, we identified the transcription factor Ets variant 2 (ETV2) as a key factor for the direct conversion of fibroblasts into ECs. ETV2 is essential for the development of ECs in vitro and in vivo. Furthermore, ETV2-induced ECs (ETVECs) significantly improve blood flow recovery in a hind limb ischemic model using BALB/c-nu mice. These results indicate that ETV2 is a promising therapeutic target for the treatment of ischemic disorders. Our study provides a new strategy for the generation of ECs and the development of vascular networks. (Show more)

The receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) are important in the development of the nervous system and in the regulation of cell growth. In the past few years, two ligands for these RTKs were discovered: ALKAL1 and ALKAL2 (also named “augmentor-β” and “augmentor-α” or “FAM150A” and “FAM150B,” respectively). Here, we show that these ligands play an important role in zebrafish pigment development. We also show that these ligands are essential for iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. These experiments establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that particular augmentors activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This work provides a new model for the study of the function of these RTKs and their ligands. Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple molecular bases. Accumulating evidence indicates that STING plays an important role in the regulation of insulin sensitivity. However, its function in β-cell remains unknown. Herein, using global and β-cell–specific knockout mouse models, we revealed a distinct role of STING in the regulation of glucose homeostasis through peripheral tissues and β-cells. Specially, although STING beneficially alleviated insulin resistance and glucose intolerance induced by high-fat diet, it surprisingly impaired islet glucose-stimulated insulin secretion (GSIS). Importantly, STING-βKO caused glucose intolerance due to impaired GSIS, indicating that STING is required for normal β-cell function. Islet transcriptome analysis showed that STING deficiency decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, including Glut2, Kcnj11, and Abcc8, contributing to impaired GSIS. Influenza A viruses are responsible for the annual occurrence of influenza epidemics and occasional severe pandemics. The genome of the virus is segmented into eight fragments, which offers evolutionary advantages but complicates genomic packaging. The selective packaging mechanism, in which one copy of each viral RNA is specifically packaged into each virion, is suspected, but its molecular details remain unknown. Here, we identified a direct intermolecular interaction between two viral genomic RNA segments of an avian influenza A virus. This interaction takes place in infected cells and is required for optimal viral replication. We also show that this interaction favors copackaging of the interacting viral RNA segments. Our results indicate that viral RNA segments can promote the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome by forming a sequence-dependent supramolecular network of interactions. The lack of conservation of these interactions might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a complex disease that is associated with a variety of risk factors, including disturbed flow. The objective of this study is to investigate the functional role of Yes-associated protein (YAP)/transcriptional coactivator with PDZ-binding motif (TAZ) in the flow regulation of atheroprone endothelial phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. We found that exposure of cultured endothelial cells (ECs) to the atheroprone disturbed flow resulted in YAP/TAZ activation and translocation into EC nucleus to up-regulate the target genes, including cysteine-rich angiogenic inducer 61 (CYR61), connective tissue growth factor (CTGF), and ankyrin repeat domain 1 (ANKRD1). In contrast, the athero-protective laminar flow suppressed YAP/TAZ activities. En face analysis of mouse arteries demonstrated an increased nuclear localization of YAP/TAZ and elevated levels of the target genes in the endothelium in atheroprone areas compared with athero-protective areas. Wildfire is a natural process that has been an integral part of the Earth system for millennia. However, human activities have greatly increased the spatial and temporal extent of wildfire in the United States and around the world. This has led to a substantial increase in the economic and ecological costs of wildfire. Although climate change has likely contributed to the increase in wildfire activity, the direct role of people in increasing wildfire activity has been largely overlooked. We show that humans have vastly expanded the geographic and seasonal “fire niche” in the United States, accounting for 84% of all wildfires and 44% of total area burned. Our results highlight the importance of reducing wildfire risk and associated hazards to ecosystems and economies.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) densely populated neighborhoods with college-educated residents are more likely to experience physical improvements; (ii) neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements; and (iii) neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our results also highlight the importance of the initial appearance of neighborhoods and the role of physical proximity in urban change. These results have implications for urban planning and policy, as well as for the study of urban change more broadly.

Natural repellents are a sustainable and eco-friendly pest control method. However, the molecular targets of natural repellents in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. We further demonstrated dTRPγ ion channel as a chemosensory receptor of natural repellents in Drosophila melanogaster. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This study is of great significance to the sustainable development of agriculture and the protection of biodiversity. The results are expected to be of great value to the development of natural repellents and the conservation of biodiversity. The findings also provide a new perspective for the study of the evolution of the ion channel gene family. The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the recent availability of a nonhuman primate model has allowed for the development of mathematical models that can be used to understand the dynamics of the virus within the host. Here we present a mathematical analysis of the within-host dynamics of ZIKV in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We also assess the effect of an antiviral treatment that blocks viral replication. Our results can be used to inform the development of treatment strategies for ZIKV infection. (Show more)

Coral reefs are among the most biodiverse ecosystems on Earth. However, they are under threat from a variety of environmental stressors, including global warming and ocean acidification. In addition, the recent mass bleaching events have highlighted the vulnerability of the coral–algal symbiosis to anthropogenic stressors. Here, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. Our findings provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help us to predict the stability of the coral holobiont in light of its metabolic interactions. This may ultimately help us to develop more effective management strategies for coral reefs.

The intestinal epithelium is a critical barrier that protects the host from the environment. In the case of cancer, the epithelium becomes leaky and allows the spread of cancer cells into the body. Here, we show that the intestinal tumor microenvironment can alter the composition of the microbiome and, in turn, the microbiome can alter the tumor microenvironment. We also show that the activity of the JNK signaling pathway is critical for maintaining the integrity of the intestinal epithelium and host–microbe homeostasis. Our work highlights the importance of controlling the activity of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. This work also provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of the microbiome in cancer progression. It also provides a potential therapeutic target for cancer treatment. (Show more)

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. The treatment of breast cancer with chemotherapy may lead to the emergence of cancer stem cells or tumor-initiating cells, which have an enhanced capacity for self-renewal, tumor initiation, and/or metastasis. Here we show that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1 is up-regulated in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also show that ROR1 expression is associated with the emergence of breast cancer stemness. Finally, we show that targeting ROR1 with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab can reduce the emergence of breast cancer stemness and improve the response to chemotherapy in mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts. These results suggest that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Show more)

The timing of the start of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is a key question in the history of the climate system. We show that the start of accelerated deglaciation at ∼17.7 ka is linked to a unique, ∼192-y series of volcanic eruptions. The eruptions likely led to stratospheric ozone depletion, which in turn caused a strong climate response. The start of deglaciation is thus likely to have been triggered by a large volcanic eruption.

Freshwater fisheries are an essential source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people worldwide. However, they are often overlooked in conservation and management efforts. We present a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also show that inland fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, highlighting the critical role of rivers in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein. Our data can be used to inform the design of conservation and management strategies that protect biodiversity and food security. We also show that the spatial coincidence of productive fisheries and low food security highlights the high stakes for improving fishery management. Our results highlight the need to consider inland fisheries in environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity. (Show more)

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. Due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited. For achieving durable and high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries, the development of negative electrode materials exhibiting a large capacity and low potential without triggering decomposition of water is crucial. The ability to regenerate after injury is a defining feature of the adult nervous system. In the mammalian CNS, however, the ability to regenerate is lost after early postnatal development. Here, we identify a form of regeneration that is remarkably independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway. This form of regeneration is triggered by physical lesion of the neuron’s sensory dendrite and is dependent on the activity of the Drosophila DLK/JNK pathway. We also identify a form of regeneration that is dependent on the activity of the mammalian DLK/MAPK pathway. These findings suggest that the mammalian nervous system has evolved multiple mechanisms to maintain its ability to regenerate. We discuss the implications of these findings for understanding the molecular control of regeneration in the adult nervous system.

The process of recombination is essential for the maintenance of genetic diversity in all organisms. In eukaryotes, recombination is initiated by the binding of proteins to specific DNA sequences. In this study, we describe the distribution of these binding sites across the genome of a flowering plant, and we show that the distribution of recombination events is also strongly influenced by the binding sites of these proteins. Our results suggest that the distribution of recombination events in plants is a conserved feature of the eukaryotic genome.

The resting brain is a dynamic system, with fluctuations in functional connectivity reflecting the activity of a large number of distributed neuronal populations. The identification of these networks is a key step in understanding the organization of the brain and its functional significance. Here, we used metabolic positron emission tomography to identify and validate reproducible resting state networks in healthy and disease populations. We found that the dominant metabolic RSN in healthy subjects was topographically similar to the default mode network. In contrast, in Parkinson’s disease (PD), this RSN was subordinated to an independent disease-related pattern. Network functionality was assessed by quantifying metabolic RSN expression in cerebral blood flow PET scans acquired at rest and during task performance. We found that the dominant RSN was deactivated during rest and activated during task performance. This abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. This work provides a new perspective on the organization of the brain in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure of messenger RNA (mRNA) is known to regulate translation. In addition to the cap, mRNA can have a variety of other modifications at the 5′ end. Here we describe a 5′ modification of RNA that is found on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded messenger RNA in yeast. We show that this modification is produced cotranscriptionally and is found on pre-mRNA and mature mRNA. This modification is found on NAD+ RNA, suggesting that it may be involved in regulating mRNA stability and translation. This modification may be a general feature of mRNA in eukaryotes.

The Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) was a landmark study in the field of diabetes research. It showed that intensive treatment of type 1 and type 2 diabetes could prevent the development of complications. However, the long-term effects of this treatment are not fully understood. We show that epigenetic DNA-methylation differences at specific loci in blood cells persist for several years after the DCCT, and that these differences are associated with glycemia. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory. This study is important because it shows that the effects of intensive treatment of diabetes are not limited to the short-term, but can have long-term effects. This may have implications for the treatment of diabetes in the future.

Fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1) is a cancer antigen expressed in the majority of breast cancer tissues and is associated with poor prognosis. However, the role of FSIP1 in the progression and drug sensitivity of triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) has not been explored. Here, we show that FSIP1 deficiency by shRNA-mediated knockdown or CRISPR-Cas9–mediated knockout significantly inhibits the proliferation and invasion of TNBC cells and impairs chemotherapy-induced growth inhibition in vivo. Computational modeling predicted that FSIP1 binds to ULK1, and this was established by coimmunoprecipitation. FSIP1 deficiency promoted autophagy, enhanced AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreased mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. In contrast, knockdown of AMPK or inhibition of autophagy restored the sensitivity to chemotherapy drugs in TNBC cells. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a chronic and relapsing disorder that affects millions of people worldwide. The etiology of this disorder is complex and involves multiple factors. In the last few years, the existence of a gut–brain axis has been suggested, which suggests that the gut microbiota may be involved in the development of alcohol dependence. In the present study, we found that some, but not all, alcohol-dependent subjects developed gut leakiness, which was associated with higher scores of depression, anxiety, and alcohol craving after 3 wk of abstinence. Moreover, subjects with increased gut permeability also had altered composition and activity of the gut microbiota. These results suggest the existence of a gut–brain axis in alcohol dependence, which implicates the gut microbiota as an actor in the gut barrier and in behavioral disorders. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved).

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals that contribute to the overall aroma. The biosynthesis of these volatiles is not known, and the contribution of nitrogenous compounds to the overall aroma is poorly understood. Here, we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all the nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. This gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylations to produce these compounds. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato aroma and will be of interest to the flavor and fragrance community. (Show more)

We show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. We demonstrate that this sensitivity is driven by changes in the thermal tolerance of species, which in turn alter the contribution of complementarity to the net biodiversity effect. Our results highlight that the impacts of global warming on ecosystem functioning are likely to be exacerbated by biodiversity loss, as the additional impacts of warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. Our findings have important implications for the functioning of ecosystems in a warming world.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a key structure in the hippocampus, which is involved in spatial memory and navigation. The organization of the MEC is important for understanding how the hippocampus encodes information about the location of objects and events in the environment. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of neurons in the MEC of freely behaving mice. We found that grid cells, which are thought to encode the location of objects and events in space, are anatomically segregated from border, head-direction, and object-vector cells. These data provide a detailed view of the organization of the MEC and will be useful for understanding how the hippocampus encodes information about the location of objects and events in the environment. Flowering is a complex process, which is controlled by a large number of genes. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FT is required for the flowering of both host and parasite. This study illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study also shows that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–dodder interactions.

Parkinson’s disease is a disorder of the dopamine-producing neurons of the substantia nigra. The cause of this disorder is unknown, but it is thought to involve a combination of genetic and environmental factors. The dopamine-producing neurons are interconnected in a circuit that includes the striatum, a brain region involved in the control of movement and motivation. We show that the dopamine-producing neurons are also interconnected in a circuit that includes the brain stem, a region involved in the control of movement and motivation. This circuit is likely to be affected in Parkinson’s disease and other disorders of the dopamine system. The striosome–dendron bouquets are a specialized form of neuronal integration that is likely to be important in the control of movement and motivation.

We are constantly interacting with others, and we often judge the quality of our interactions by how well we feel connected. But how do we know when we are feeling connected? We conducted a series of experiments to show that the speed with which we respond to others is a robust and honest signal of connection. We found that people felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. This signal was used by third-party listeners to judge the quality of the interaction. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for generating the heart rate. The SAN is also the site of the electrical activity that initiates each heartbeat. The electrical activity of the SAN is regulated by a complex network of ion channels and stores of intracellular Ca2+. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of the electrical activity of the SAN. We show that STIM1 is selectively expressed in the specialized cardiomyocytes of the SAN and that its deletion in mice leads to a reduction in the number of Ca2+ stores in these cells. This, in turn, leads to a reduction in the electrical activity of the SAN. These studies reveal a previously unknown role for STIM1 in the regulation of the electrical activity of the SAN. The beneficial effects of silicon (Si) on plant growth and stress tolerance have been well documented, but the function of Si in plant defense against herbivores has not been well understood. Here, we show that Si pretreatment enhances rice resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, and that this effect is mediated by the jasmonate (JA) signaling pathway. Our results suggest that Si and JA may interact to promote plant defense against herbivores. This study provides a new perspective on the role of Si in plant defense. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We demonstrate that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activation of macrophages and that modulation of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages and suggest that alteration of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids. Our findings have implications for the understanding of the role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism and for the treatment of phenylketonuria. They also suggest that modulation of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity may be a promising approach for the treatment of inflammatory diseases. This study also provides a new model for the study of the role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism.

Language is a complex system that involves the integration of information over time. The neural basis of this integration is not well understood. Here we propose a mechanism for memory that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it is sensitive to the duration of memory. This mechanism is not reliant on the maintenance of high firing rates, and it is not limited to the storage of information in the form of spikes. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in plant biology. Herein, we report the delivery of siRNAs to plants with DNA nanostructures. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment locus of the DNA nanostructure determine the internalization efficiency and corresponding gene silencing efficiency. Our work establishes the feasibility of delivering biomolecules to plants with DNA nanostructures and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is a step toward the development of DNA nanostructures as a tool for plant biology. Eutrophication is a major threat to aquatic ecosystems worldwide, driven largely by nonpoint nutrient loading from surrounding watersheds. However, decades of monitoring and regulatory efforts have focused almost exclusively on the largest watersheds, overlooking the role of smaller tributaries. We show that the 6 largest tributaries of Lake Michigan account for ∼70% of the daily nutrient loads delivered to the lake. However, small tributaries exhibit nutrient loads that are high for their size and biased toward dissolved inorganic forms. This suggests that nutrient inputs from small watersheds may be more important than previously thought in fueling coastal algal blooms. Our findings highlight the importance of small watersheds in driving coastal eutrophication and provide a framework for targeting nutrient management efforts to reduce the ecological impacts of nutrient loading on valuable nearshore ecosystems. We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “saddle-node” bifurcation, which is a well-known phenomenon in dynamical systems theory. We discuss the implications of our results for the study of complex networks and for the design of chemical systems that can operate in the presence of strong environmental bias.

The mechanisms by which antibodies against the N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptor cause autoimmune encephalitis are poorly understood. Here we show that NMDAR-Ab antibodies can change the spectral composition of spontaneous EEG activity and predispose brain dynamics to paroxysmal abnormalities. We validate a dynamic causal model of NMDAR-Ab effects on cortical microcircuitry and show that key synaptic parameters can explain EEG paroxysms in pediatric patients with NMDAR-Ab encephalitis. Finally, we show that NMDAR-Ab–related changes render microcircuitry critically susceptible to overt EEG paroxysms when these key parameters are changed. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Ab. They also suggest that the same parameter fluctuations that are tolerated in the in silico model of the control condition can lead to overt EEG paroxysms when these parameters are changed, even though the same parameter fluctuations are not tolerated in the in silico model of the condition. The Earth system is currently experiencing a rapid warming event, which is unprecedented in the last 2,000 y. The cause of this warming is unknown, but it is likely related to the injection of large amounts of organic matter into the ocean. The organic matter is likely derived from the destruction of large marine organisms, such as trilobites, which are abundant in the geological record. The organic matter is a valuable source of carbon, which can be used to fuel the global warming. The organic matter injection is also likely to have caused a global warming.

The palm oil industry is responsible for substantial tropical deforestation, and many major corporations and countries have made commitments to purchase or produce only “sustainable” palm oil. Certification is the tool most used to fulfill these procurement policies, and around 20% of global palm oil production was certified by the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) in 2017. However, the effect of certification on deforestation in oil palm plantations remains unclear. Here, we use a comprehensive dataset of RSPO-certified and noncertified oil palm plantations (∼188,000 km2) in Indonesia, the leading producer of palm oil, as well as annual remotely sensed metrics of tree cover loss and fire occurrence, to evaluate the impact of certification on deforestation and fire from 2001 to 2015. Our results suggest that certification reduced deforestation in Indonesia. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. The exocyst complex is a multisubunit protein complex that is essential for the last steps of exocytosis. It is conserved from bacteria to humans. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. The exocyst complex is evolutionarily conserved in plants, and its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. However, the study of the dynamic regulation of the exocyst-related processes in plants is limited by the severity of phenotypes. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the genetic basis of sex determination is a key component of sex differentiation. In vertebrates, sex determination is often a single locus, but in some species, multiple sex determination alleles interact to produce more than two genotypic sexes. Here we investigate the effects of multiple interacting sex determination alleles in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii, where two alleles (W and Y) interact to produce siblings with four possible sex classes: ZZXX females, ZWXX females, ZWXY females, and ZZXY males. We find that multiple alleles can produce modular variation in morphological and behavioral traits, and that the introgression of a newly acquired sex determiner can create additional axes of variation for varied traits. These results provide context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of multiple interacting sex determination alleles in populations. (Show more)

The retina is a highly oxidative tissue that is challenged by the accumulation of bisretinoids, which are formed by the photooxidation of vitamin A aldehyde adducts. We sought to understand how iron (Fe) impacts the retina, given that retinal pigment epithelial (RPE) cells are also challenged by accumulations of bisretinoids. We found that Fe levels impact the retina. In albino mice with reduced Fe levels, as measured by the transferrin receptor, bisretinoid levels were reduced. In mice with increased Fe levels, as measured by the hephaestin and ceruloplasmin knockout, bisretinoid levels were increased. These findings indicate that Fe promotes the formation of bisretinoids. This interpretation was supported by experiments showing that Fe reduced the oxidative/degradation of the bisretinoid A2E in the presence of light and reduced cell death in cell-based experiments. Moreover, light-independent oxidation and degradation of A2E by Fenton chemistry products were evidenced by the consumption of A2E, release of dicarbonyls, and generation of oxidized A2E species in cell-free assays. These findings have implications for the treatment of age-related macular degeneration. (Read more)

Predators are the key to understanding how ecosystems function, and how they have evolved. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, as it is difficult to evolve morphological and functional optimizations in separate structures. Here we show that siphonophores, a group of pelagic predators, can evolve specialization on different prey types. Our results suggest that the evolution of specialization is linked to the evolution of morphological and functional innovations in separate structures. These findings contribute to a broader perspective on predatory niche diversification, and help us understand how specialization has shaped present-day food webs.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolutionary biology. The study of the evolution of the hand is complicated by the fact that the hand is a complex and multifunctional organ, and the fossil record is incomplete. Here we report the discovery of a hominin hand from East Africa that preserves evidence for a key derived feature of the human hand, the third metacarpal styloid process. This fossil provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of this feature and suggests that it arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo. This finding has implications for the evolution of the human hand and the origins of modern human-like tool use. (Show more)

Cancer is a metabolic disease, and thus the study of cancer metabolism is a major focus of cancer research. The enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) is a key metabolic enzyme, converting serine to glycine and a folate-bound one-carbon unit. In mammals, SHMT1 is cytosolic, and SHMT2 is mitochondrial. We show that dual knockout of SHMT1 and SHMT2 blocks colon cancer tumor growth in mice. We also identify small-molecule dual inhibitors of SHMT1 and SHMT2, and demonstrate that they are effective in cellular assays. Finally, we show that formate can rescue cells from SHMT inhibition, but paradoxically increases the inhibitor’s cytotoxicity in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL. These results suggest that SHMT inhibition is a promising therapeutic strategy for cancer, and that formate-based inhibitors are a promising lead for drug development. Collectively, these results suggest that SHMT inhibition is a promising therapeutic strategy for cancer.

The importance of forests in improving people’s diets is not well understood. This study shows that deforestation can reduce people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables and thus their vitamin A adequacy. Conversely, forest fragmentation can increase people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables and thus their vitamin A adequacy. These findings have important implications for policy makers, who should consider the role of forests in improving people’s diets and nutrition security.

The use of farm machinery has greatly increased the capacity of modern agriculture, allowing for the expansion of arable land and food production. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, the sauropods, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
